lines.text: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO and MOTH

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Warble, child; make passionate my sense of hearing.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Concolinel. DON
Singing

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years; take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither: I must employ him in a letter to my love.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl? DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: How meanest thou? brawling in French?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, my complete master: but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humour it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometime through the nose, as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes; with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away. These are complements, these are humours; these betray nice wenches, that would be betrayed without these; and make them men of note--do you note me?--that most are affected to these. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: How hast thou purchased this experience?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: By my penny of observation. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: But O,--but O,--

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: 'The hobby-horse is forgot.' DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Callest thou my love 'hobby-horse'?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, master; the hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love? DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Almost I had.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Negligent student! learn her by heart. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By heart and in heart, boy.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And out of heart, master: all those three I will prove. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: What wilt thou prove?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without, upon the instant: by heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I am all these three.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Fetch hither the swain: he must carry me a letter.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A message well sympathized; a horse to be ambassador for an ass. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Ha, ha! what sayest thou?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slow-gaited. But I go. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The way is but short: away!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: As swift as lead, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The meaning, pretty ingenious? Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I say lead is slow.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: You are too swift, sir, to say so: Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun? DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet smoke of rhetoric! He reputes me a cannon; and the bullet, that's he: I shoot thee at the swain.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Thump then and I flee. DON
Exit

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: A most acute juvenal; voluble and free of grace! By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face: Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place. My herald is return'd.
Re-enter MOTH with COSTARD

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A wonder, master! here's a costard broken in a shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Some enigma, some riddle: come, thy l'envoy; begin.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: No enigma, no riddle, no l'envoy; no salve in the mail, sir: O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain! no l'envoy, no l'envoy; no salve, sir, but a plantain! DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly thought my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l'envoy, and the word l'envoy for a salve?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Do the wise think them other? is not l'envoy a salve? DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: No, page: it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain. I will example it: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee, Were still at odds, being but three. There's the moral. Now the l'envoy.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I will add the l'envoy. Say the moral again. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee, Were still at odds, being but three.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Until the goose came out of door, And stay'd the odds by adding four. Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with my l'envoy. The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee, Were still at odds, being but three. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Until the goose came out of door, Staying the odds by adding four.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A good l'envoy, ending in the goose: would you desire more?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that's flat. Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat. To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose: Let me see; a fat l'envoy; ay, that's a fat goose. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin. Then call'd you for the l'envoy.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: True, and I for a plantain: thus came your argument in; Then the boy's fat l'envoy, the goose that you bought; And he ended the market. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: But tell me; how was there a costard broken in a shin?

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I will tell you sensibly.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth: I will speak that l'envoy: I Costard, running out, that was safely within, Fell over the threshold and broke my shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: We will talk no more of this matter.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Till there be more matter in the shin. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: O, marry me to one Frances: I smell some l'envoy, some goose, in this. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person; thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: True, true; and now you will be my purgation and let me loose. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance; and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: bear this significant to the country maid Jaquenetta: there is remuneration; for the best ward of mine honour is rewarding my dependents. Moth, follow.
Giving a letter
Exit

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: My sweet ounce of man's flesh! my incony Jew! Now will I look to his remuneration. Remuneration! O, that's the Latin word for three farthings: three farthings--remuneration.--'What's the price of this inkle?'--'One penny.'--'No, I'll give you a remuneration:' why, it carries it. Remuneration! why, it is a fairer name than French crown. I will never buy and sell out of this word.
Exit MOTH
Enter BIRON

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: O, my good knave Costard! exceedingly well met.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: What is a remuneration?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Why, then, three-farthing worth of silk.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I thank your worship: God be wi' you!

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Stay, slave; I must employ thee: As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave, Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: When would you have it done, sir?

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: This afternoon.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Well, I will do it, sir: fare you well.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Thou knowest not what it is.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Why, villain, thou must know first.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I will come to your worship to-morrow morning.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: It must be done this afternoon. Hark, slave, it is but this: The princess comes to hunt here in the park, And in her train there is a gentle lady; When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name, And Rosaline they call her: ask for her; And to her white hand see thou do commend This seal'd-up counsel. There's thy guerdon; go.
Giving him a shilling

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Gardon, O sweet gardon! better than remuneration, a'leven-pence farthing better: most sweet gardon! I will do it sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!
Exit

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: And I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been love's whip; A very beadle to a humorous sigh; A critic, nay, a night-watch constable; A domineering pedant o'er the boy; Than whom no mortal so magnificent! This whimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy; This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid; Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms, The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, Liege of all loiterers and malcontents, Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, Sole imperator and great general Of trotting 'paritors:--O my little heart:-- And I to be a corporal of his field, And wear his colours like a tumbler's hoop! What, I! I love! I sue! I seek a wife! A woman, that is like a German clock, Still a-repairing, ever out of frame, And never going aright, being a watch, But being watch'd that it may still go right! Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all; And, among three, to love the worst of all; A wightly wanton with a velvet brow, With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes; Ay, and by heaven, one that will do the deed Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard: And I to sigh for her! to watch for her! To pray for her! Go to; it is a plague That Cupid will impose for my neglect Of his almighty dreadful little might. Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue and groan: Some men must love my lady and some Joan. LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
Exit
